content:
The "Violence Against Children Act of 2003" may be cited as such. Congress finds that individuals under 18 account for a significant portion of crime victims, especially in sex crimes and kidnappings. Adolescents aged 12-17 are more than twice as likely to be victims of violent crime compared to adults. Only 28% of crimes against children are reported, leading to a significant underreporting of abuse cases. Approximately 1,200 children die from abuse annually, with around 879,000 children being victims of abuse, which has long-lasting negative effects. Child abuse has long-lasting negative effects on children and families, including delayed development, depression, substance abuse, and increased likelihood of experiencing or perpetrating domestic violence as an adult. Most local agencies lack resources to protect children and families adequately. Failure to pay child support is a form of neglect, leading to children living in poverty and facing challenges in education, healthcare, and housing. Local agencies often lack resources to support children and families in need. Title I of the legislation focuses on enhancing the federal role in addressing crimes against children, including the implementation of enhanced penalties. Title I of the legislation enhances federal penalties for crimes against children, including imprisonment for up to 10 years and fines. Additionally, those responsible for injuring a person under 18 years of age may face life imprisonment and fines if death results from the offense. Threatening or causing harm to a person under 18 years of age can result in imprisonment for up to 10 years and fines. If death occurs or if the offense involves kidnapping, sexual abuse, or attempted murder, the perpetrator may face life imprisonment and fines. The offense can result in life imprisonment and fines if death occurs or if it involves kidnapping, sexual abuse, or attempted murder during travel across state lines or national borders. The circumstances for penalties under this section include conduct across state lines or national borders, or using interstate or foreign commerce channels, facilities, or weapons. The penalties under this section apply to offenses involving interstate or foreign commerce and the use of weapons that have traveled in interstate or foreign commerce. The United States Sentencing Commission will enhance penalties for crimes against children under federal law. The Comptroller General will review state laws regarding penalties for crimes against children within 6 months of the Act's enactment. The Comptroller General of the United States will review state laws on penalties for crimes against children within 6 months of the Act's enactment, especially focusing on enhanced penalties when the victim is a child. SEC. 102. ENHANCED ASSISTANCE FOR CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS AND PROSECUTIONS BY STATE AND LOCAL LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICIALS. The Attorney General provides assistance in criminal investigations or prosecutions of violent crimes against minors at the request of a State, Indian tribal government, or local government. If resources are insufficient, priority is given to fulfilling requests. The Attorney General provides assistance in criminal investigations or prosecutions of violent crimes against minors at the request of a State, Indian tribal government, or local government. Priority is given to crimes committed by offenders who have committed crimes in more than 1 State and rural jurisdictions facing extraordinary expenses. TITLE II--GRANT PROGRAMS

SEC. 201. FEDERAL ASSISTANCE TO STATE AND LOCAL LAW ENFORCEMENT. The Attorney General awards grants to States, Indian tribal governments, and local units for law enforcement and prosecution of crimes against children. The grants provide personnel, training, technical assistance, data collection, and equipment to apprehend and prosecute offenders. Training is provided for law enforcement officers, prosecutors, judges, and court personnel to effectively respond to crimes against children. The grants awarded by the Attorney General provide equipment and training to law enforcement officers, prosecutors, judges, and court personnel to effectively identify and respond to crimes against children. This includes developing specialized units and implementing policies to prevent, identify, and respond to such crimes. The grants awarded by the Attorney General focus on developing specialized units of law enforcement officers, prosecutors, and courts targeting crimes against children. This includes implementing effective policies, protocols, and data collection systems to prevent, identify, and respond to such crimes. The Attorney General grants focus on developing specialized units targeting crimes against children, including implementing data collection systems and enhancing collaboration between law enforcement and child services agencies. The Attorney General grants aim to enhance collaboration between law enforcement and child services agencies, as well as address the needs of Indian tribes in dealing with crimes against children. States, Indian tribal governments, or local governments must submit an application to the Attorney General to receive a grant under this section. The Attorney General grants aim to address the needs of Indian tribes in dealing with crimes against children. States, Indian tribal governments, or local governments must submit an application with required information to receive a grant. To apply for an Attorney General grant, a State, Indian tribal government, or local government must provide necessary information as requested. This includes detailing the grant's purpose, intended use of funds, and expected outcomes. To apply for an Attorney General grant, the applicant must demonstrate the need for the grant, the intended use of funds, and the expected results. Additionally, they must consult and coordinate with victim services programs experienced in helping victims of crimes against children. To apply for an Attorney General grant, the State, Indian tribal government, or unit of local government must consult and coordinate with victim services programs experienced in helping victims of crimes against children. They must also certify that any Federal funds received will supplement, not supplant, non-Federal funds for the funded activities. The State, Indian tribal government, or unit of local government must certify that Federal funds will supplement, not supplant, non-Federal funds for activities funded under this section. Authorization of $25,000,000 is provided for this purpose. Authorization of $25,000,000 is provided for each fiscal year 2004 through 2008 to ensure compliance with sections 301 and 302 by the State, Indian tribal government, or unit of local government. SEC. 202. EDUCATION, PREVENTION, AND VICTIMS' ASSISTANCE GRANTS. The Attorney General awards grants to assist in providing education, prevention, intervention, and victims' assistance services for crimes against children. Grants are used for educational seminars, hotlines, and training programs for professionals. The Attorney General awards grants to provide education, prevention, and intervention services for crimes against children, including seminars, hotlines, training programs, informational materials, and intervention services. Other efforts include increasing awareness and prevention of crimes against children in underserved communities. The Attorney General awards grants for education, prevention, and intervention services for crimes against children, including informational materials, emergency medical treatment, counseling, and increasing mental health professionals specializing in victims of crimes against children. The Attorney General awards grants for education, prevention, and intervention services for crimes against children, including emergency medical treatment, counseling, and increasing mental health professionals specializing in victims of crimes against children. Each entity seeking a grant must submit an application to the Attorney General. Each entity seeking a grant for education, prevention, and intervention services for crimes against children must submit an application to the Attorney General with required information. Entities applying for a grant must describe the purposes, intended use, and expected results of the grant funds, as well as demonstrate a plan for implementing the grant. Entities applying for a grant must describe the purposes, intended use, and expected results of the grant funds, as well as demonstrate a plan for implementing the grant by consulting and coordinating with victim services. Entities applying for a grant must implement the grant by consulting and coordinating with victim services programs experienced in helping victims of crimes against children. Entities applying for a grant must work with nonprofit victim services programs experienced in crimes against children and certify their experience in providing relevant services. The organization must have experience in providing education, prevention, or intervention services for crimes against children or victims of such crimes. They must certify that any federal funds received will supplement, not supplant, non-federal funds for these activities. The organization must certify that any federal funds received will supplement, not supplant, non-federal funds for activities funded under this section. The Attorney General may waive this requirement for nongovernmental organizations in extraordinary circumstances. The Attorney General may waive the requirement for nongovernmental organizations in extraordinary circumstances, as long as the state or tribal government is in compliance with section 303. The government or nongovernmental organization must comply with section 303. $25,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2004 to 2008. TITLE III--NATIONWIDE PROGRAMS

SEC. 301. NATIONWIDE AMBER ALERT.

Each State receiving grants must establish a statewide AMBER Alert network for child abduction cases within 3 years.

SEC. 302. IMPROVED STATISTICAL GATHERING.

States must use or develop protocols to use the National Incident-Based Reporting System.

SEC. 303. NATIONAL SAFE HAVEN. Each State receiving grants under this Act must have a statute allowing parents to leave a newborn with a hospital employee anonymously without penalty, collect family medical history with parent approval, and involve law enforcement after child relinquishment. The State's Safe Haven law includes provisions for hospital employees to collect family medical history with parent approval, involve law enforcement in searching missing person databases after child relinquishment, and publicize the law. The State's Safe Haven law requires searching missing person databases for relinquished children and publicizing the law. An exception allows denying anonymity if a newborn shows signs of abuse. SEC. 304. IMPROVED CHILD PROTECTION SERVICES PROGRAMS. Each State receiving child welfare services funding must submit a report on their program within 180 days. The General Accounting Office will report to Congress on State practices and policies under the child welfare program. The General Accounting Office will report to Congress on State practices and policies under the child welfare program funded under subpart 1 of part B of title IV of the Social Security Act. The report will include how States are maintaining records and verifying the well-being of children under their care. The General Accounting Office will report to Congress on State practices and policies under the child welfare program. This includes how States are maintaining records, verifying the well-being of children, tracking their whereabouts, reviewing system reforms, implementing best practices, and recommending legislative changes. TITLE IV--CHILD SUPPORT ENFORCEMENT

SENSE OF THE SENATE ON TAX TREATMENT OF CHILD SUPPORT: Congress should pass legislation to extend Federal tax treatment to nonpayment of child support by allowing deductions for recipients and adding unpaid amounts to the income of non-paying parents for tax purposes.
